At Court of. Probate holden ct Litch-

 field, sUithin and for the district of Litch-

 field, May 29h 1927.

 Present, F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge. TTPON the Petition of SARAH REY- U NOLDS, of Washington in said District, showing to this Court that she is Guardian. of Ralph P. Reynolds and David B. Reynolds, both of said Washington. minor children of Josiah Reynolds, late of Washington, deceas- ed that said minors are the owners in fee as Tenants in common of two certain pieces of land situate in said Washington in New-Pres- ton Society, the first piece containing about thirty five acres, with a dwelling house and other buildings thereon, which buildings and five acres of land are subject to said Sarah's right of dover. The second piece contains about half an acre, known by the name of '' the Island."-Said two pieces of land being bounded as set forth in the petition, praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on fle dated May 29, 1927. Whereupon this Court doth order that said petition be contin- 6ed to the second Monday in August next at ten o'clock A. M. then to be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Litchfeld in said District, and that notice of the pendan- cy of said petition be given by publishing this Order in Newspaper printed in said Litch- field three weeks successively, at least six weeks before said second Monday in August next.

 true Copy of Record. 50 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge.

THE Court of Probate for the District of -A Litchield hath assigned Wednesday, the goth day of instant June, at o'clock in the forenoon, at the Probate Office in Litchield, in said district, for the appointment of Com nssioners on the estate of

 URIEL HOLMES, Esq. late of said Litchfeld, deceased, represented insolvent; at which time and place all persons interested in said estate will, if they see cause, attend before said court, and be heard respec- ting such appointment.

 By order of said court,

 HENRY HOLMES, Adeinis-

 LEONARD GOODWIN, { trutors. Litchfield, June 5, 1897. 51

DEUBEN MERRIMAN would inform AN the public that he has opened Shop in Litchfeld, a few rods east of the Meeting house at the Stand lately occupied by I. Bunce Esq. where he will attend to the business of Clock and Watch repairing, and Silver Smith, and keeps on hand an assortment ot such ar ticles as are usually called for in his line, as low as can be bought elsewhere, among which are Silver Spectacles, Spoons, Jewelry, Sc. also few first rate Brass eight day Clocks. He solicits a share of the public patronage.

 As a DENTIST he will set teeth in the best manner>for those who may favour him with their custom.-Cash paid for old Silver.

 Litchield, May 50, 1927. 50
NOTICE.

REUEL CoGSwELL'S ESTATE. VTHE Hon. Court Of Probate for the dis N trict of Lisch6eld having appointed tho Subscribers Commissioners to receive and ad- just the claims of the creditors of the estate of

 REUEL COGSWELL, late of Washington in said district deceased, represented insOlvent, give notice that we will attend to the duties of our appointment, at the house of the late deceased, on the first Thursdays of September and December next, at 10 o'clock A. M. on each of said days.

 Six months from the 10th day of June are allowed the creditors to present their claims properly attested.

 ENSIGN BUSHNELL, } (,om.;.

 BIRDsEYE BEARDsLEY, c2""s.'- s;"".s.

 NATHAN NEWTON,

 Washington, May 28, 1926. 90

INVENTED by John Brown of Providence -A is worthy of the patronage of every eco nomical farmer, or mechanic, who would man. ufacture in the family for their own use. So far they can be satisfied by their use on trial One girl will spin on these machines five runs of yarn for one days work, and with more ease and in less time than she can spin two runs on the common wheel. and besides the yarn is evener and better. Some girls have gone far beyond this, even to fourteen runs.- The above mentioned machine can be had by applying to Solon Bishop of Bradleys-Ville, Litchfeld, or Philo Chase in Milton, and all instructions given necessary for the use of the same. The price will be invariably twenty dollars each.

 SOLON BISHOP &

 PHILO CHASE, Agents for REUBEN RICE & WM. HILL, Wal lingford, Ct.

THE Co-partnership heretofore existing N under the firm of Chapin, Collins & O.. was dissolved on the Sd inst. by the death of Asaph Wright, one of the partners to said manufacturing business will be continued by the subscribers under the firm of Chapin, Collins & Walter.

 SAMUEL CHAPIN,

 TIMOTHY COLLINS,

 ALFRED WALTER,

 JOHN H. COLLINS,

 CICERO COLLINS. Goshen, 95th May. 1897. 30

 SILAS P. WRIGHT, } 11:o

A Meeting of the Executive Committee "A Ofthe Agricultural society of the County of Litch6eld will be held on Wednesday, the goth day of June, inst. at 2 o'clock P. M. at s. Deming's Hotel.

 LitchiieId, June, 6, 1927.

Just received, and for sale at the |LITCHFIELR BOOKSTORE A new supply of Superior SILVER STEEL RAZORS, warranted to suit the purchaser. From the knowledge we have in this article, and the perfect satisfaction expressed by those who have heretofore purchased razors of us, we feel confident in recommending it to those who wish to procure a first rate razor; and also in warranting that fit does not do good service we will pay back the purchase money for the article

 Also, Barber's Old English Razors, uni versaly y approved" Razors ofthe Famous Damascus Blade."

 new and elegant supply of PEN and POCKET KNIVES, of a great variety of prlces and patterns, from. common, to best double refined and silver steel. The choic- est articles in the stationary line are kept con- stantly for sale at the above store

 Also, received within few days quanti- ,y of very superior Letter, Foolscap, and Pot hot-pressed PAPER, for sale by the Ream or single quire. Grown and Post Wrapping Paper.

 A CIRCULATING LIBRARY, has been just commenced at the above store, contain ing about 400 volumes of choice modern works consisting of Theological, Biographical, His torical. and Miscellaneous, together with sev- cral of the best periodical publications of the country. Terms, $500 per year, with free access to the library, or 12 1-s cts. for oc- tavos, and cts. for duodecimos, per week. New works will be added as fast as they are issued from American presses.

 Litchfield, May so, 1827
Just received, and for sale at the LITCHFIELR BOOKSTORE

for business on Monday. at i, P. M. The officers of last year were reelected, ex- cept the Hon. Samuel Hubbard was cho- sen President in the place of the Hon. William Philips deceased. A Delegation from the Presbyterian Education Society was present, and the union of that society with this as Branch SOciety,wa consum- mated. The delegation were the Rev. Messrs. Hamilton, Patton and E. Lcrd Esq. In consequence of the Union, a large number of members were elected and the constitution was so altered as to enlarge the number of Directors from to 13, the number 5 still forming quorum. The new Directors chosen are John Tap pan Esq. of Boston, Author Tappan Esq. and Rev. c. Spring D. D. of New Y ork, and Hon. John c. Smith of Connecticut. The constitution was also amended, so as to give the election of Secretary to the So- ciety, ,instead of the Directors. The mee- tings of the Society are no longer confined to Boston, but may may be appointed to other places by the Directors.

 At half past the Society convened in Hanover Church 10 hear the report of the Directors and Addresses. The Rev. c. Hitchcock commenced with prayer. The report was read by the Rev. K. Cornelius, the Secretary. Motions were made or seconded by J. Evarts Esq, of Boston 1; E. Lord Esq, of New-Yo ork; Rev. E. Hooker of Goshen Conn. Rev. Mir. Patton, of the city of New ork Profess sor Newman, of Bowdoin College 1: Rev. MT. Hamilton, of Newark, N. J.; and Rev. Dr. Beecher, of Boston. All these gentlemen, except MT. Lord, addressed the meeting.

 MT. Evarts alluded to objections which were raised twelve years ago, when this society commenced its opperations, and inquired whether time eand experience had confirmed them, or removed them. lie believed he might, on this ground, chal- ienge for the Society complete and ab- solute triumph. 1t was said. there was not in our country very great Restitution of ministers ; ;but careful and extensive investigation has sweled the nnmber of waste places far beyond the first computa- tions. It was said, that numerous beneti- charles could not be procured; but the Lord hath raised them up. 1t was said, if they were prepared, they would not be received and settled; but the demand has increased beyond the supply, and calls for laborers were never more numerous or urgent than at the present moment It was alter wards said. some may not prove useful and successful preachers but the society IS not required to guarantya perfect charac- ter, or eminent usefulness. The church must still take ministers as imperfect men. and depend on God to make them useful. He believed that the plan and opperations of this body were now firmly established :; and that the prosecution of them would lead to glorious results. MT. E. adverted to the appointment of a Secretary or Gen. cral Agent, to be solely devoted to the concerns of the institution; and expressed his conviction, that such a measure is de- sirable for all the principal benevolent so- cieties. Yet Christians at large should not feel, that such agents will do the whole work; but should remember them with traternal regard, and each perform his own part as assigned him in the providence of God.

 Dr. Beecher remarked, that the laws of the natural world are uniform; and if it is not always so in the moral world, still some things are certain. We can have no doubt that the population of this great country will increase, and that we shall become a vast people; or that the spirit of enter prise will continue and increase abundant ly; or that these causes, unless counterac- ted, will nightly extend moral corruption. 1t is certain too, that tRefs' will be rsla- tive decrease of moral power, unless very special and powerful effort be made to sustain and increase it. We may, .howev- CT, bless God, that for this moral corrup- .tion and desolation there is remedy. There is power that can effect this, and but one. That is the gospel. Science, philosophy, legislation cannot do it. The gospel can do it. And in preparing min isters for the whole country, we send forth streams from that fountain to heal the land. We stand at the head of the most impor- tant river of influence ever known. How wicked are they, who stand there and aug ment the poison and death. How guilty are those who stand there with the gospel of healing in their hands, and do nothing. We as a society have undertaken the work, and we must march on as an united phalanx to accomplish it.-Again. success ascertain. There is gospel enough there will he hands enOuUh to carry if thera
From the Boston Recorder. AMERICAN EDUCATION SOCIETY

collrres; in Brown University, in Wash 1 inCton College, in Connecticut, tn Colom- l bian College, and iut the University OfGeOr- 1 gia,: go have been pursuing studies prepar- atOry tO entering college, in eight different a. cademies.

 Results ofpast eforts.-The whole number of young men to whom appropriations have been made since the foundation of the sOcie- ty in 1915 is fUe hundred aud SeUeRty-Sir. They have resided in nineteen, or tGCeRty, states and have pursued their studies in as many colleges, and at more than forty acad- emies. Some have been aided only for few months, and others through the whole course of their academic studies.

 The Secretary has paid particular atten- tiOn to the result of past efforts, which is ye- ry difficult to ascertain with accuracy. Yet the information which he has received, in ad- ditiOn to what the Directors before possessed, enables, them to communicate the following statement of facts.-Of those who have been patronized by the Society from it's com mencement. 73 have been settled as Pastors Of churches, in l4 different States; all of whom, it is believed, yet sustain that office, except 4 or " ho have died or been dismiss ed. Six or seven have devoted themselves to the work of foreign Missionaries two of these. the lamented Mosely and Chapman, have already ceased from their lab0rs, and their bodies lie buried far in the wilderness of America. Four have been ordained aa E- UGngeiists, and others as Domestic MisSion- aries. Thirty three are preaching as LiccD- ti0teS and Candidates for settlement; secen are Licentiotes, and at the same time, {'astruc- tors of youth; and ttCo others who have re- ceived ordination, have been called to sta tlons of eminent usefulness, in connexlOn with two of the largest benevolent societies in the country. Thus it. is ascerttined, that of those whom lht' society has assisted since its formation only ttoeiye years ego oFE aUND- RED AND TH5nTY-sEv&N have become prea- chers of the Gospel. Their voice is heard every Sabbath day, by thousands and tens of thousands of immortal beings in various and remote places of our lands. Some of them have been blessed with reviyals of religion and every year sWeliS the number of those who will regard lhein, forever, as the nstru ments, under God, of their salvation. Forty .fue are employed as Teachers, four as pro fsssors, or tutors, in colleges, and the remain ing number, for the most part, as instructors, for a time, Of academies.

 Not far from haif of He 'ohole nwnaber sOho haUe receiued aid from the society, are now in various stages of their preparatory studies. About one h:fadred md .ffty are in academies and colleges, IS has brcn mentioned already. Between si1tV and serenity are members of various Theological sGniIlarles and several others are attcnf,ingto theological studies un- der the directions of private ministers. From tlOenty to thirty it is expected will finish their, preparatory course, and commence preaching the present yo"I.

 Funds.-.'hc amount of donations and of other sources ot Alsposi,ble income during the year, as appears from the Treasurer's report, is SlS,428 ga. The amount of expenditures is S12,OOs C9. About sixty scholarships of 5000 each have been subscribed, part of them payable in five years, and a large part has already been paid into the hands of the Treasurer on account of them. DISTRIBUTION OF TRACTS IN NETWORK.

 At meeting of the managers of the New York City Tract Society, many interesting facts were related, relative to the circulation of Tracts in this city. One gentleman be- longing to the Hucksters' committee, had di- rected his attention particularly to Fulton, Franklin and Catharine Markets; and had distributed to the amount of 1S,OOO pages Other gentleman of the Board, not on the Committee for distribution, expressed a de- sire to receive Tracts, and it was finally re- solved that any member of the Board might draw upon the Chairman of the Executive Committee, for whatever amount he might wish to distribute, on condition of reporting to the Board, as. far as practicable, the beni- fcial effects. Should funds be wanted to meet the necessary expenses, it was believed they would be promptly supplied.

 The Committee of Steam boats reported that they had supplied II boats, each with 12 volums of Tracts, neatly bound. In every case they were thankfully received, and as- surance was given that they would be care fully preserved, and devoted to the use of the passengers.

 The Shipping Committee reported that since their organization, their Chairman had given orders for 113,OOO pages of Tracts, near ly all of which have been distributed. It was the united voice of the Committee, that seamen are ready, willing, and in many cases anxious, to receive the messages of mercy. One of the number reported the following incidents:

 ''I supplied the crew of the ship Huron with Tracts, and among the rest a man who was intoxicated ;-though dobted the pro- priety of giving any to him. Not long after l met this man and had the happiness to find him sober. He took me by the hand in a most friendly manner, and said The Tracts you gave me are very good things; was Ips,IN RN1A

\ HEREBY forbid all persons trusting my A wife Maria, as I will pay no debts of her contracting after this date.

 HERMAN SEELYE. LitchfeId, May 23, 1927. 50

for business on Monday. at i, P. M. The officers of last year were reelected, ex- cept the Hon. Samuel Hubbard was cho- sen President in the place of the Hon. William Philips deceased. A Delegation from the Presbyterian Education Society was present, and the union of that society with this as Branch SOciety,wa consum- mated. The delegation were the Rev. Messrs. Hamilton, Patton and E. Lcrd Esq. In consequence of the Union, a large number of members were elected and the constitution was so altered as to enlarge the number of Directors from to 13, the number 5 still forming quorum. The new Directors chosen are John Tap pan Esq. of Boston, Author Tappan Esq. and Rev. c. Spring D. D. of New Y ork, and Hon. John c. Smith of Connecticut. The constitution was also amended, so as to give the election of Secretary to the So- ciety, ,instead of the Directors. The mee- tings of the Society are no longer confined to Boston, but may may be appointed to other places by the Directors.

 At half past the Society convened in Hanover Church 10 hear the report of the Directors and Addresses. The Rev. c. Hitchcock commenced with prayer. The report was read by the Rev. K. Cornelius, the Secretary. Motions were made or seconded by J. Evarts Esq, of Boston 1; E. Lord Esq, of New-Yo ork; Rev. E. Hooker of Goshen Conn. Rev. Mir. Patton, of the city of New ork Profess sor Newman, of Bowdoin College 1: Rev. MT. Hamilton, of Newark, N. J.; and Rev. Dr. Beecher, of Boston. All these gentlemen, except MT. Lord, addressed the meeting.

 MT. Evarts alluded to objections which were raised twelve years ago, when this society commenced its opperations, and inquired whether time eand experience had confirmed them, or removed them. lie believed he might, on this ground, chal- ienge for the Society complete and ab- solute triumph. 1t was said. there was not in our country very great Restitution of ministers ; ;but careful and extensive investigation has sweled the nnmber of waste places far beyond the first computa- tions. It was said, that numerous beneti- charles could not be procured; but the Lord hath raised them up. 1t was said, if they were prepared, they would not be received and settled; but the demand has increased beyond the supply, and calls for laborers were never more numerous or urgent than at the present moment It was alter wards said. some may not prove useful and successful preachers but the society IS not required to guarantya perfect charac- ter, or eminent usefulness. The church must still take ministers as imperfect men. and depend on God to make them useful. He believed that the plan and opperations of this body were now firmly established :; and that the prosecution of them would lead to glorious results. MT. E. adverted to the appointment of a Secretary or Gen. cral Agent, to be solely devoted to the concerns of the institution; and expressed his conviction, that such a measure is de- sirable for all the principal benevolent so- cieties. Yet Christians at large should not feel, that such agents will do the whole work; but should remember them with traternal regard, and each perform his own part as assigned him in the providence of God.

 Dr. Beecher remarked, that the laws of the natural world are uniform; and if it is not always so in the moral world, still some things are certain. We can have no doubt that the population of this great country will increase, and that we shall become a vast people; or that the spirit of enter prise will continue and increase abundant ly; or that these causes, unless counterac- ted, will nightly extend moral corruption. 1t is certain too, that tRefs' will be rsla- tive decrease of moral power, unless very special and powerful effort be made to sustain and increase it. We may, .howev- CT, bless God, that for this moral corrup- .tion and desolation there is remedy. There is power that can effect this, and but one. That is the gospel. Science, philosophy, legislation cannot do it. The gospel can do it. And in preparing min isters for the whole country, we send forth streams from that fountain to heal the land. We stand at the head of the most impor- tant river of influence ever known. How wicked are they, who stand there and aug ment the poison and death. How guilty are those who stand there with the gospel of healing in their hands, and do nothing. We as a society have undertaken the work, and we must march on as an united phalanx to accomplish it.-Again. success ascertain. There is gospel enough there will he hands enOuUh to carry if thera
The amount Of money received by the SO- ciety since it's organization, (lsth February last,) is SS5e; Se; of which S8ll; 4A have been paid over to the Parent SOciety.-l An. IT.. Mag.l

collrres; in Brown University, in Wash 1 inCton College, in Connecticut, tn Colom- l bian College, and iut the University OfGeOr- 1 gia,: go have been pursuing studies prepar- atOry tO entering college, in eight different a. cademies.

 Results ofpast eforts.-The whole number of young men to whom appropriations have been made since the foundation of the sOcie- ty in 1915 is fUe hundred aud SeUeRty-Sir. They have resided in nineteen, or tGCeRty, states and have pursued their studies in as many colleges, and at more than forty acad- emies. Some have been aided only for few months, and others through the whole course of their academic studies.

 The Secretary has paid particular atten- tiOn to the result of past efforts, which is ye- ry difficult to ascertain with accuracy. Yet the information which he has received, in ad- ditiOn to what the Directors before possessed, enables, them to communicate the following statement of facts.-Of those who have been patronized by the Society from it's com mencement. 73 have been settled as Pastors Of churches, in l4 different States; all of whom, it is believed, yet sustain that office, except 4 or " ho have died or been dismiss ed. Six or seven have devoted themselves to the work of foreign Missionaries two of these. the lamented Mosely and Chapman, have already ceased from their lab0rs, and their bodies lie buried far in the wilderness of America. Four have been ordained aa E- UGngeiists, and others as Domestic MisSion- aries. Thirty three are preaching as LiccD- ti0teS and Candidates for settlement; secen are Licentiotes, and at the same time, {'astruc- tors of youth; and ttCo others who have re- ceived ordination, have been called to sta tlons of eminent usefulness, in connexlOn with two of the largest benevolent societies in the country. Thus it. is ascerttined, that of those whom lht' society has assisted since its formation only ttoeiye years ego oFE aUND- RED AND TH5nTY-sEv&N have become prea- chers of the Gospel. Their voice is heard every Sabbath day, by thousands and tens of thousands of immortal beings in various and remote places of our lands. Some of them have been blessed with reviyals of religion and every year sWeliS the number of those who will regard lhein, forever, as the nstru ments, under God, of their salvation. Forty .fue are employed as Teachers, four as pro fsssors, or tutors, in colleges, and the remain ing number, for the most part, as instructors, for a time, Of academies.

 Not far from haif of He 'ohole nwnaber sOho haUe receiued aid from the society, are now in various stages of their preparatory studies. About one h:fadred md .ffty are in academies and colleges, IS has brcn mentioned already. Between si1tV and serenity are members of various Theological sGniIlarles and several others are attcnf,ingto theological studies un- der the directions of private ministers. From tlOenty to thirty it is expected will finish their, preparatory course, and commence preaching the present yo"I.

 Funds.-.'hc amount of donations and of other sources ot Alsposi,ble income during the year, as appears from the Treasurer's report, is SlS,428 ga. The amount of expenditures is S12,OOs C9. About sixty scholarships of 5000 each have been subscribed, part of them payable in five years, and a large part has already been paid into the hands of the Treasurer on account of them. DISTRIBUTION OF TRACTS IN NETWORK.

 At meeting of the managers of the New York City Tract Society, many interesting facts were related, relative to the circulation of Tracts in this city. One gentleman be- longing to the Hucksters' committee, had di- rected his attention particularly to Fulton, Franklin and Catharine Markets; and had distributed to the amount of 1S,OOO pages Other gentleman of the Board, not on the Committee for distribution, expressed a de- sire to receive Tracts, and it was finally re- solved that any member of the Board might draw upon the Chairman of the Executive Committee, for whatever amount he might wish to distribute, on condition of reporting to the Board, as. far as practicable, the beni- fcial effects. Should funds be wanted to meet the necessary expenses, it was believed they would be promptly supplied.

 The Committee of Steam boats reported that they had supplied II boats, each with 12 volums of Tracts, neatly bound. In every case they were thankfully received, and as- surance was given that they would be care fully preserved, and devoted to the use of the passengers.

 The Shipping Committee reported that since their organization, their Chairman had given orders for 113,OOO pages of Tracts, near ly all of which have been distributed. It was the united voice of the Committee, that seamen are ready, willing, and in many cases anxious, to receive the messages of mercy. One of the number reported the following incidents:

 ''I supplied the crew of the ship Huron with Tracts, and among the rest a man who was intoxicated ;-though dobted the pro- priety of giving any to him. Not long after l met this man and had the happiness to find him sober. He took me by the hand in a most friendly manner, and said The Tracts you gave me are very good things; was Ips,IN RN1A

\ HEREBY forbid all persons trusting my A wife Maria, as I will pay no debts of her contracting after this date.

 HERMAN SEELYE. LitchfeId, May 23, 1927. 50
